content.text: The pile contains 500 sheets of paper
Calculate the average thickness of one sheet of paper
average thickness =   .........  \(cm\)
Show that the pile of paper has a volume of \(3000 \text{cm}^3\). Use the information shown in Fig. 1.1
The student measures the total mass of the paper in the pile
State the name of a device used to measure mass
The mass of the paper in the pile is \(2400 \text{g}\)
Calculate the density of the paper
A student has a pile of A4 paper for his computer printer
Fig. 1.1 shows the dimensions of the pile of paper
Fig.1.1 (not to scale)
Tick the box that represents the cyclist travelling at constant speed
Calculate the distance travelled by the cyclist in the first 5 seconds
distance =   .........  m
Fig. 2.1 shows the speed-time graph for one cyclist
Calculate the average speed of this cyclist
average speed =   .........  m/s
A friend of the cyclist starts a stopwatch at the beginning of the race
Fig.2.2 shows the reading on the stopwatch when the cyclist has gone around the track once
Fig.2.3 shows the reading on the stopwatch when the cyclist has gone around the track twice
Calculate the time taken for the cyclist to go around the track during the second lap
The length of the track is 250 m
Another cyclist goes around the track four times (four laps). This takes 80.0 seconds
Some cyclists are racing around a track
Determine the extension of spring A for a load of 10 N
extension =   .........  mm
State which spring is easier to stretch and give a reason for your answer
spring
reason
Calculate the extension of this spring for a load of 6.0 N
extension =   .........  \(cm\)
Describe how a student could use the equipment in Fig. 3.2 to obtain accurate readings for a load-extension graph for this spring
[Total: 6]
A different spring is suspended from the edge of a bench, as shown in Fig. 3.2
Fig.3.2 Fig.3.3
With no load on the spring, the pin points to 19.7 cm on the metre rule, as shown in Fig. 3.2. When a load of 6.0 N is attached to the spring, the pin points to 43.9 cm, as shown in Fig. 3.3
Fig. 3.1 shows the load-extension graphs for two springs, A and B
Describe how the power station uses the water in the reservoir to generate electrical energy
State three advantages of generating electrical energy using a hydroelectric system compared with using a coal-fired power station
The electric drill **usefully** transforms electrical energy into ....................... energy.
A second electric drill transforms the same amount of electrical energy per second as the first one. It wastes more of this energy
The second drill is **less** ..................................... than the first drill
An electric drill is shown in Fig. 4.2. It uses electrical energy
Complete the sentences about the electric drill
Use words from the box. Each word may be used once, more than once, or not at all
Fig. 4.1 represents a hydroelectric system for generating electrical energy
State what happens to the pressure of the air in the bottle
Explain why the pressure of the air in the bottle changes. Use your ideas about gas molecules
The air in the bottle becomes warmer
The bottle has a weight of \(5.4 \text{N}\) and an area of \(9.2 \text{cm}^2\) in contact with the table
Calculate the pressure produced by the bottle on the table. Give the unit
pressure =   .........
The base of the bottle is circular. The radius of the outer circle is \(4.0 \text{cm}\) as shown in Fig. 5.3. Calculate the area of this circle
The bottle shown in Fig. 5.2 has the same mass as the bottle shown in Fig. 5.1. Explain why the bottle shown in Fig. 5.2 exerts more pressure on the table than the bottle shown in Fig. 5.1
Fig. 5.2 shows another bottle. The bottle is on a table. Part of the base of this bottle is not in contact with the table
Fig. 5.3 shows the base of the bottle. The shaded area is **not** in contact with the table
Fig. 5.1 shows a glass bottle containing air. The bottle is sealed with a cap
State a physical property that varies with temperature and can be used in a thermometer
Suggest the time at which the heater is switched off
Suggest the time at which the curtains were closed and explain your answer. Use information from the graph
time
explanation
Fig. 6.1 shows how the temperature of the room changes between 6:00 pm and 11:00 pm

A heater in the room is switched on at 6 pm. The room has a large window. A large amount of thermal energy is transferred through the window. The window in the room has thick curtains. Closing the curtains reduces the loss of thermal energy from the room
In cool climates, people use mineral wool to reduce heat loss from houses. Mineral wool is made of fibres and trapped air, as shown in Fig. 6.2
Use words from the box to complete the sentences. Each word may be used once, more than once, or not at all
Air is a good
When air is trapped between fibres, it reduces heat loss by ....................................... and by
A thermometer is used to measure the temperature inside a room in a house
State which angle w, x, y or z, is the angle of refraction
Light is a transverse wave
State another example of a transverse wave
A ray of light refracts as it travels from air into glass, as shown in Fig. 7.1
On Fig. 7.2, draw three wavefronts that have passed through the gap
State the name of the effect in (b)(i)
Fig. 7.2 represents some wavefronts approaching a barrier with a narrow gap
measure the total current in the circuit
vary the current in the lamp B only
measure the potential difference (p.d.) across lamp B
On Fig. 8.1, draw the circuit symbols for three devices so that the student can:
The current in lamp A is 0.20A. The potential difference (p.d.) across lamp A is 6.0V
Calculate the resistance of lamp A
resistance =   .........  \(\Omega\)
A student sets up an electrical circuit. She draws part of the circuit diagram, as shown in Fig. 8.1
State which region has waves with the longest wavelength
Fig. 9.1 represents the seven main regions of the electromagnetic spectrum
Tick the box for the wave with the lowest speed in air
ultraviolet
ultrasound
visible light
A group of students want to determine the speed of sound in air
Describe a method they can use. State the measurements they need to make
A teacher demonstrates electromagnetic induction using the apparatus shown in Fig. 10.1

The teacher pulls the magnet down until one end is inside the coil. The teacher then releases the magnet. The magnet moves up and down repeatedly. As it moves, one end of the magnet enters and leaves the coil
Describe and explain the readings on the centre-zero millivoltmeter as the magnet enters and leaves the coil
Fig. 10.2 shows a system for transmitting electricity from a power station
State the name of the device used in X and the name of the device used in Y
X
Y
A student rubs a polythene rod with a dry cloth. The polythene rod becomes negatively charged
Describe and explain how the rod becomes negatively charged
The negatively charged polythene rod hangs from a nylon thread so that it is free to turn
The student charges a second polythene rod and brings it close to the first rod, as shown in Fig. 11.1
Describe and explain what happens when the negatively charged rods are close to each other
Fig. 12.1 shows a radioactive source placed close to a radiation detector and counter. The detector can detect \(\alpha\) , \(\beta\) and \(\gamma\) radiation
The radioactive source emits \(\beta\) -particles only
Describe how you could show that the source emits \(\beta\) -particles only
As part of your answer, you may draw on Fig. 12.1 and add any other apparatus you may need
